occurrences.line_text: But ere the point arriued, where it ought,
For now arriued is his fatall howre,
From whence eftsoones arriued here three hoyes
Till they arriued, where they lately had
They bene ymet, and both their points arriued,
And where their Lady was, arriued at the last.
So long they sought, till they arriued were
And by what accident she there arriued:
As she arriued on the roring shore,
His speare amids her sun-broad shield arriued;
And now by fortune was arriued here,
But when the victoresse arriued there,
The dreadfull stroke in case it had arriued,
Staid not, till it arriued in his side.
And now the Knights being arriued neare,
Arriued, shee with great humility
Soone after whom the Prince arriued there,
It was not long, till that the Prince arriued
Ere that huge stroke arriued on him neare,
So now they be arriued both in sight
And night arriued hard at hand, began
Arriued in this Isle though bare and blunt,
There auncient Night arriuing, did alight
The pointed steele arriuing rudely theare,
That the sharpe steele arriuing forcibly
Atin arriuing there, when him he spide,
And here arriuing, strongly challenged
The Squire arriuing, fiercely in his armes
Arriuing, him with multitude oppresse;
The Damzell there arriuing entred in;
Where soone arriuing, they restrained were
At last arriuing by the listes side,
There this faire crewe arriuing, did diuide
And in his nape arriuing, through it thrild
Arriuing there, he found this wretched man,
When Artegall arriuing happily,
Where they arriuing, by the watchmen were
Where soone arriuing they receiued were
There he arriuing boldly, did present
Where he arriuing with the fall of day,
Arriuing there, as did by chaunce befall,
So growen great through arrogant delight
And in my heart his yron arrow steepe,
Whose right haunch earst my stedfast arrow strake?
Drew out a deadly bow and arrow keene,
But the false Archer, which that arrow shot
Another arrow hath your louers hart to hit.
And therewith shot an arrow at the lad;
Of life, whom late their Ladies arrow ryu'd:
And through his soule like poysned arrow perst,
The arrow, to his deadly marke desynde,
She sent an arrow forth with mighty draught,
With that selfe arrow, which the Carle had kild:
Wandreth alone with bow and arrowes keene,
For thy fierce arrowes, them to exercize,
And mortall arrowes, wherewith he doth fill
And euery one did bow and arrowes beare:
Their fluttring arrowes, thicke as flakes of snow,
And many arrowes vnder his right side,
His wicked arrowes, gathered them againe,
Of some wild beast, which with her arrowes keene
And turne his arrowes to their exercize:
Whom hauing slaine, through luckles arrowes glau[n]ce
Of broken bowes and arrowes shiuered short,
A mortall bow and arrowes keene did hold,
With bow in hand, and arrowes ready bent,
With fell despight her cruell arrowes tynde
Her mortall arrowes she at him did threat,
With a sharpe showre of arrowes, which them staid,
And arrowes haild so thicke, that they could not abide.
Of Artegals arryuall, her to free,
Arryuing, to his kyne for food assynd;
Her mournefull plaintes, beguiled of her art,
Art thou misshaped thus, as now I see?
But what art thou, that telst of Nephews kilt?
Where was a Caue ywrought by wondrous art,
Them brought to ï¿½sculape, that by his art
And all things else, the which his art did teach:
Great maistresse of her art was that false Dame,
But if thou be, as thou art pourtrahed
Till I that treachours art haue heard and tride;
Why shouldst thou then despeire, that chosen art?
Ay me, deare Lady, which the image art
And whether art it were, or heedlesse hap,
But what art thou, ï¿½ Ladie, which doest raunge
Ne should faire Claribell with all her art,
For proofe thereof, this euening, as thou art,
But read how art thou nam'd, and of what kin.
Art thou now bound? for well mote I discerne
And ouer him, art striuing to compaire
That here in Ladies lap entombed art,
Calling thy helpe in vaine, that here in ioyes art dround.
Art Lord, and eke of nature Soueraine,
Their natiue musicke by her skilfull art:
That art thus foully fled from famous enemie?
What art thou man, (if man at all thou art)
What art thou man, (if man at all thou art)
But wrought by art and counterfetted shew,
Which Merlin made by his almightie art
To whom Cymochles said; For what art thou,
How that thou art partaker of his crime:
He built by art vpon the glassy See
That art in mighty armes most magnifide
That natures worke by art can imitate:
Wherewith her mother Art, as halfe in scorne
So made by art, to beautifie the rest,
The art, which all that wrought, appeared in no place.
Art, and that Art at nature did repine;
Art, and that Art at nature did repine;
If pourtrayd it might be by any liuing art.
But liuing art may not least part expresse,
Entyst the Boy, as well that art she knew,
For pleasing words are like to Magick art,
And to their purpose vsed wicked art:
Which Bladud made by Magick art of yore,
Thou art the root and nurse of bitter cares,
Of euery thing consumes, and calcineth by art.
There was a pleasant arbour, not by art,
Now when the Beast, which by her wicked art
The maisters of her art: there was she faine
For all that art he learned had of yore.
Troy, that art now nought, but an idle name,
So perfect in that art was Paridell,
Of all the passions in the mind thou vilest art.
Yet thou vile man, vile Scudamore art sound,
Where force might not auaile, their sleights and art
Figuring straunge characters of his art,
So great a mistresse of her art she was,
Which she by art could vse vnto her will,
Such as the maker selfe could best by art deuize.
Who vnderstanding by her mightie art,
What medicine can any Leaches art
That workst such wrecke on her, to whom thou dearest art.
How euer she her paynd with womanish art
Vaine is the art that seekes it selfe for to deceiue.
That all so soone as he by wit or art
Art playing second natures part, supplyed it.
Thou art the root of all that ioyous is,
But where so loose or happy that thou art,
Of my mishaps, art mou'd to wish me better,
Thereto adde art, euen womens witty trade,
The art of mightie words, that men can charme;
In minde he grew, for feare least by that art
Of armes has knighthood stolne, yet Knight art none,
Some Clarkes doe doubt in their deuicefull art,
So much more then is that of powre and art,
And turne thee soone to him, of whom thou art defyde.
Art thou the caytiue, that defyest me,
For by no art, nor any leaches might
As he the art of words knew wondrous well,
Art thou he, traytor, that with treason vile,
Whereof thou caytiue so vnworthie art;
Or learn'd the art to please, I doe not fynd.
Which to recure, no skill of Leaches art
And art thou yet aliue, whom dead I long did faine.
Now take the right likewise, sayd Artegale,
describeth Artegall:
the state of Artegall.
And Artegall doth quell.
At Artegall, in middest of his pryde,
But Artegall beholding his mischaunce,
Beheld the louely face of Artegall,
He thus bespake; Certes Sir Artegall,
Soone as she heard the name of Artegall,
And you Sir Artegall, the saluage knight,
But Artegall close smyling ioy'd in secret hart.
All being guided by Sir Artegall.
In all which time, Sir Artegall made way
Sir Artegall, who all this while was bound
The instrument whereof loe here thy Artegall.
Artegall trayn'd in Iustice lore
The Champion of true Iustice Artegall.
Chose Artegall to right her to restore;
For Artegall in iustice was vpbrought
And willed him with Artegall to wend,
Who was it then (sayd Artegall) that wrought?
When to the place they came, where Artegall
But Artegall by signes perceiuing plaine,
Whom when so willing Artegall perceaued;
Much did that Squire Sir Artegall adore,
Artegall heares of Florimell,
But of her health when Artegall did heare,
Ne was Sir Artegall behinde: so both
Which oddes when as Sir Artegall espide,
Ne euer Artegall his griple strong
So Artegall at length him forst forsake
For Artegall in swimming skilfull was,
But Artegall was better breath'd beside,
But Artegall pursewd him still so neare,
That Artegall him selfe her seemelesse plight did rew.
Sir Artegall vndid the euill fashion,
All which when Artegall did see, and heare,
Then answered the righteous Artegall,
Well then, sayd Artegall, let it be tride.
But Artegall him fairely gan asswage,
In warlike wise, when Artegall did vew,
To Artegall he turn'd, and went with him throughout.
Sir Artegall into the Tilt-yard came,
Who came not forth, but for Sir Artegall
All which when Artegall, who all this while
But Artegall that golden belt vptooke,
Which troublous stirre when Artegall perceiued,
Which Artegall well hearing, though no more
Thereby Sir Artegall did plaine areed,
So did he mitigate Sir Artegall;
That when as time to Artegall shall tend,
Artegall dealeth right betwixt
Then this of Artegall, which here we haue to say.
When Artegall arriuing happily,
Then Artegall thus to the younger sayd;
And each one had his right. Then Artegall
Now when as Artegall arriu'd in place,
How hight that Amazon (sayd Artegall?)
Whom when as Artegall in that distresse
But Artegall him selfe to rest did dight,
Artegall fights with Radigund
Then forth came Artegall out of his tent,
So did Sir Artegall vpon her lay,
Thus there long while continu'd Artegall,
To Artegall, through pittie of his causelesse smart.
Some men, I wote, will deeme in Artegall
That it was Talus, Artegall his groome;
By Artegall, through his owne guilty wile;
Was Artegall, by many tokens plaine;
Which still was wont with Artegall remaine;
On which Pollente with Artegall did fight.
And Artegall thence frees.
Made them sweare fealty to Artegall.
Meane while her noble Lord sir Artegall
Prince Arthure and Sir Artegall,
Yet could it not sterne Artegall retaine,
Sir Artegall, to whom she streight did hie
Like fiercely met. But Artegall was stronger,
Sir Artegall, without discretion
Tho when as Artegall did Arthure vew,
Then Artegall gan of the Prince enquire,
First, that sir Artegall should him array,
So as they had deuiz'd, sir Artegall
By Artegall, misween'd for her owne Knight,
But Artegall being thereof aware,
Then Artegall himselfe dicouering plaine,
Arthur and Artegall catch Guyle
Where righteous Artegall her late exyled;
Where hauing with Sir Artegall a space
But Artegall him after did pursew,
And to his Lord Sir Artegall it lent,
But Artegall with constant firme intent,
The noble Prince, and righteous Artegall,
And leauing Artegall to his owne care;
Ne after him did Artegall abide,
But turne we now to noble Artegall;
Did much abash Sir Artegall to heare,
Now turne againe (Sir Artegall then sayd)
Of whom Sir Artegall gan then enquire
But why haue ye (said Artegall) forborne
To whom thus Artegall; Certes Sir knight,
Fie on such forgerie (said Artegall)
Sir Artegall, albe he earst did wyte
Sayd Artegall; What foule disgrace is this,
But Artegall seeing his cruell deed,
Artegall doth Sir Burbon aide,
Gainst whom Sir Artegall, long hauing since
The whyles Sir Artegall, with that old knight
Till Artegall him seeing so to rage,
That night Sir Artegall did cause his tent
Sir Artegall, in battailous array
When Artegall she saw in that array,
With dreadfull looke he Artegall beheld,
Which cruell outrage when as Artegall
Which Artegall perceiuing, strooke no more,
And linckt together gainst Sir Artegall,
Sir Artegall return'd from his late quest,
If her Sir Artegall had not preserued,
With Artegall, returning yet halfe sad
To whom Sir Artegall gan to expresse
What is that quest (quoth then Sir Artegall)
Sayd Artegall, I such a Beast did see,
Now God you speed (quoth then Sir Artegall)
of Artegals mishap,
The certaine cause of Artegals detaine;
Of Artegals arryuall, her to free,
His Magick bookes and artes of sundry kindes,
Who all this while with charmes and hidden artes,
Which still she bore, replete with magick artes;
His artes he moues, and out of caytiues hands
All artes, all science, all Philosophy,
They haue exceld in artes and pollicy,
And all the artes, that subtill wits discouer,
As Arthegall, and Sophy now beene honored.
The which I seeke to wreake, and Arthegall he hight.
The noble Arthegall hath euer borne the name.
Achilles armes, which Arthegall did win.
The spouse of Britomart, is Arthegall:
But most of Arthegall, and his estate.
She learned had th'estate of Arthegall,
Though knowne to few, that Arthegall he hight,
But thereat greatly grudged Arthegall,
Both Scudamour and Arthegall
But toward th'end Sir Arthegall renewed
Prince Arthur meets with Vna great-
brings Arthur to the fight,
His loues and lignage Arthur tells
Aread Prince Arthur, crowne of Martiall band?
Prince Arthur gaue a boxe of Diamond sure,
Thus beene they parted, Arthur on his way
Sith her Prince Arthur of proud ornaments
Prince Arthur is, that wonnes in Faerie lond;
Whom Arthur soone hath reskewed
Prince Arthur, flowre of grace and nobilesse,
So rag'd Prince Arthur twixt his foemen twaine,
So did Sir Guyon[Prince Arthur] beare himselfe in fight,
Till Arthur all that reckoning did defray;
Prince Arthur them repelles, and fowle
And seeke aduentures, as he with Prince Arthur went.
Faire Florimell of Arthur is
Prince Arthur heares of Florimell:
And from Prince Arthur fled with wings of idle feare.
Prince Arthur stints their strife.
Now after that Prince Arthur graunted had,
Arthur and Artegall catch Guyle
Prince Arthur takes the enterprize
Prince Arthur and young Timias, which met
His owne deare Lord Prince Arthure came that way,
And is by Arthure slaine.
Prince Arthure and Sir Artegall,
Tho when as Artegall did Arthure vew,
Prince Arthure ouercomes the great
till she Prince Arthure fynd,
By Arthure, when as Vnas Knight he did maintaine.
Prince Arthure ouercomes Disdaine,
They met Prince Arthure with Sir Enias,
But Arthure with the rest, went onward still
Of his sharpe darts and whot artillerie;
And planted there their huge artillery,
Th'end of his drift, he praisd his diuelish arts,
Quoth then the knight, by whose mischieuous arts
So when he saw his flatt'ring arts to fayle,
As when her face is staynd with magicke arts constraint.
No magicke arts hereof had any might,
Who by her wicked arts, and wylie skill,
Not he, whom Greece, the Nourse of all good arts,
Whose footsteps Bladud following in arts
Tryde all her arts, & all her sleights, thence out to wrest.
And hellish arts from people she might hide,
And by her deuilish arts thought to preuaile,
Or Arts, but Oxford thine doth Thame most glorify.
Although Blandina did with all her arts
For Aruirage his brothers place supplide,
Nor dred of Romanes, then was Aruirage,
As time her taught, in lowly Shepheards weeds,
As much disdayning to the curbe to yield:
As one for knightly giusts and fierce encounters fitt.
And dead as liuing euer him ador'd:
And euer as he rode, his hart did earne
As one that inly mournd: so was she sad,
So pure and innocent, as that same lambe,
Of needments at his backe. Thus as they past,
And as she lay vpon the durtie ground,
Soone as that vncouth light vpon them shone,
For light she hated as the deadly bale,
As Lyon fierce vpon the flying pray,
As when old father Nilus gins to swell
Deformed monsters, fowle, and blacke as inke,
As gentle Shepheard in sweete euen-tide,
Her scattred brood, soone as their Parent deare
Of such as drunke her life, the which them nurst;
And all the way he prayed, as he went,
And often knockt his brest, as one that did repent.
Who faire him quited, as that courteous was:
And well could file his tongue as smooth as glas;
And well could file his tongue as smooth as glas;
As messenger of Morpheus on them cast
As still are wont t'annoy the walled towne,
As one then in a dreame, whose dryer braine
Remounted vp as light as chearefull Larke,
Remounted vp as light as chearefull Larke,
In sort as he him schooled priuily:
He started vp, as seeming to mistrust,
And as halfe blushing offred him to kis,
For all so deare as life is to my hart,
So slyding softly forth, she turnd as to her ease.
As one aghast with feends or damned sprights,
As her slow beast could make; but all in vaine:
For her he hated as the hissing snake,
As many formes and shapes in seeming wise,
As euer Proteus to himselfe could make:
The red bloud trickling staind the way, as he did ride.
As when two rams stird with ambitious pride,
Astonied both, stand sencelesse as a blocke,
So stood these twaine, vnmoued as a rocke,
As from a forge out of their burning shields,
Who after her as hastily gan scowre,
With loue, long time did languish as the striken hind.
Let fall her eyen, as shamefast to the earth,
But this good knight soone as he them can spie,
With goodly purposes there as they sit:
Art thou misshaped thus, as now I see?
As raging flames who striueth to suppresse.
With whom as once I rode accompanyde,
Mine, that did then shine as the Morning starre:
His Lady left as a prise martiall,
Frï¿½lissa was as faire, as faire mote bee,
Frï¿½lissa was as faire, as faire mote bee,
And euer false Duessa seemde as faire as shee.
And euer false Duessa seemde as faire as shee.
Eftsoones I thought her such, as she me told,
Soone as appeard safe opportunitie:
As all vnweeting of that well she knew,
Though true as touch, though daughter of a king,
Though faire as euer liuing wight was faire,
Farre from all peoples prease, as in exile,
As the great eye of heauen shyned bright,
Soone as the royall virgin he did spy,
But to the pray when as he drew more ny,
As he her wronged innocence did weet.
As the God of my life? why hath he me abhord?
But with her went along, as a strong gard
As if her life vpon the wager lay,
Soone as she parted thence, the fearefull twaine,
And in the way as she did weepe and waile,
That should as death vnto my deare hart light:
As you to leaue, that haue me loued still,
Much like, as when the beaten marinere,
Soone as the port from farre he has espide,
Who told her all that fell in iourney as she went.
As euer wielded speare in warlike hand,
And a rich throne, as bright as sunny day,
And a rich throne, as bright as sunny day,
A mayden Queene, that shone as Titans ray,
As enuying her selfe, that too exceeding shone.
For she was wondrous faire, as any liuing wight.
Soone as the Elfing knight in presence came,
As faire Aurora in her purple pall,
That seemd as fresh as Flora in her prime,
That seemd as fresh as Flora in her prime,
Still as he rode, he somewhat still did eat,
With precious mettall full, as they might hold,
Still as he rode, he gnasht his teeth, to see
As ashes pale of hew and seeming ded;
So oft as Slowth still in the mire did stand.
Of proud Lucifer', as one of the traine:
But threw his gauntlet as a sacred pledge,
And Phoebus fresh, as bridegrome to his mate,
As when a Gryfon seized of his pray,
Soone as the Faerie heard his Ladie speake,
As when a wearie traueller that strayes
Whom when she found, as she him left in plight,
That on their rustie bits did champ, as they were wood.
Her twyfold Teme, of which two blacke as pitch,
They binden vp so wisely, as they may,
As giuing warning of th'vnwonted sound,
But Ladies loue as losse of time forbore:
Scattered on euery mountaine, as he went,
A ruefull sight, as could be seene with eie;
And him as onely God to call vpon,
And would as Ammons sonne be magnifide,
Whose case when as the carefull Dwarfe had tould,
As when a ship, that flyes faire vnder saile,
As rocke of Diamond stedfast euermore.
Then gan her beautie shine, as brightest skye,
As her outrageous foe had left her late,
As when a greedie Wolfe through hunger fell
They all as glad, as birdes of ioyous Prime,
They all as glad, as birdes of ioyous Prime,
Do worship her, as Queene, with oliue girlond cround.
And worship her as Goddesse of the wood;
Did loue as life, aboue all worldly blisse;
By straunge aduenture as it did betyde,
That his beheast they feared, as tyrans law,
They traueild had, when as they farre espide
For feare as seemd, or for some feigned losse;
As he had traueild many a sommers day,
And soone he came, as he the place had ghest,
As when two Bores with rancling malice met,
Whom all so soone as that proud Sarazin
As to descry the crafty cunning traine,
Was out of Dianes fauour, as it then befell.
Be such as she her selfe was then in place.
Drunke of the streame, as cleare as cristall glas;
Drunke of the streame, as cleare as cristall glas;
He had beene pouldred all, as thin as flowre:
He had beene pouldred all, as thin as flowre:
As when that diuelish yron Engin wrought
To gayne so goodly guerdon, as she spake:
Who her as willingly to grace did take,
Such one it was, as that renowmed Snake
And all embrewd in bloud, his eyes did shine as glas.
And prowdly threw to ground, as things of naught;
All as the Dwarfe the way to her assynd:
But when as monsters huge he would dismay,
As when a cloud his beames doth ouer-lay;
As when her face is staynd with magicke arts constraint.
But all that was not such, as seemd in sight,
Who vnder him did trample as the aire,
When as this knight nigh to the Ladie drew,
Soone as I thinke vpon my bitter bale:
My loyalty, not such as it did seeme;
So oft as he through his owne foolish pride,
With staring countenance sterne, as one astownd,
As when almightie Ioue in wrathfull mood,
